content.text: ● Use the adhesive putty to attach the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass to the metre rule as close as possible to the \(80\mathrm{cm}\) mark, as shown in Fig. 1.1
● The distance between the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark and the centre of the mass is \(L\)
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.2
● Suspend the rule from the long string loop at the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
● Add the two \(50 \text{g}\) masses to the mass hanger to make a total mass \(m\) of \(110 \text{g}\). Suspend mass \(m\) from the spring
● The distance between the string loop supporting the spring and the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(b\)
The distance between the top of the top loop of the spring and the bottom of the bottom loop of the spring is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 1.2
Adjust the position of the string loop supporting the spring until the rule is horizontal and in equilibrium
Repeat **(b)** with different values of \(m\) until you have six sets of readings. Record \(m\), \(x\) and \(b\). Include your values from **(b)**
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{b}\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{b}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
It is suggested that the quantities \(b\) and \(x\) are related by the equation
Using your answers in (d)(iii), determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\)
A student repeats the experiment placing the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass closer to the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule
Theory suggests that \(P\) and \(Q\) are both inversely proportional to \(L\)
For this experiment, draw a second line on the graph to show the expected results
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a metre rule
You have been provided with a cup. The diameter of the base of the cup is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
Pour boiling water into the cup until it is approximately one-third full
When the temperature of the water is \(75^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), start the stop-watch
After two minutes, measure and record the temperature \(\theta\)
The height of the water in the cup is \(h\) and the diameter of the surface of the water is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 2.2
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(h\). Show your working
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of C
Repeat (b), (c)(i) and (c)(iii) with the cup approximately two-thirds full
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)
Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(\Delta \theta\), \(h\) and \(C\) is
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment, you will investigate how the rate of cooling of a hot liquid depends on its volume
